questions.question_text: Which of the following indicates that it may be appropriate to use a clustering key for a table? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
D&E
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/tables-clustering-keys.html#:~:text=for%20a%20Table-,What,-is%20a%20Clustering
DE I think
D and E are correc answers

Selected Answer: DE
DE are correct

Selected Answer: DE
Some general indicators that can help determine whether to define a clustering key for a table include:

Queries on the table are running slower than expected or have noticeably degraded over time.

The clustering depth for the table is large.

Selected Answer: DE
correct ans
Why not A?

comments.content:
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/tables-clustering-keys

A column with very low cardinality might yield only minimal pruning, such as a column named IS_NEW_CUSTOMER that contains only Boolean values. 

In other words, very low cardinality columns may not be worth clustering (the way I read it).

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
Correct

DE
 Queries on the table are running slower than expected or have noticeably degraded over time.
The clustering depth for the table is large. 
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/tables-clustering-keys#label-considerations-for-choosing-clustering

Selected Answer: DE
I think D E

Selected Answer: DE
Answer is D and E 
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/tables-clustering-keys.html#what-is-a-clustering-key

choices.D: Queries on the table are running slower than expected.
choices.B: DML statements that are being issued against the table are blocked.
choices.E: The clustering depth for the table is large.
choices.C: The table has a small number of micro-partitions.
choices.A: The table contains a column that has very low cardinality.

questions.question_text: Which cache type is used to cache data output from SQL queries?

discussion.content:
Result Cache:  Which holds the results of every query executed in the past 24 hours. These are available across virtual warehouses, so query results returned to one user is available to any other user on the system who executes the same query, provided the underlying data has not changed.
Local Disk Cache:  Which is used to cache data used by SQL queries. Whenever data is needed for a given query it's retrieved from the Remote Disk storage, and cached in SSD and memory.

comments.content: Result Query is stored at Cloud Service layer

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I am looking what Kate 02024 wrote. I am seeing that the question is about SQL queries, in this case, answer is D.

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes how clustering keys work in Snowflake?

choices.A: Clustering keys update the micro-partitions in place with a full sort, and impact the DML operations.
choices.C: Clustering keys create a distributed, parallel data structure of pointers to a table's rows and columns.
choices.D: Clustering keys establish a hashed key on each node of a virtual warehouse to optimize joins at run-time.
choices.B: Clustering keys sort the designated columns over time, without blocking DML operations.

questions.question_text: Which of the following operations require the use of a running virtual warehouse? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
C & E
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses.html

comments.content: Sorry I think virtual warehouse is needed for material view but it fetches the data quicker than running a full table scan.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Material view does not require a warehouse
C and E are correct

Selected Answer: CE
CE are correct
C and E is the answer

Selected Answer: AD
Performing DML operations, such as:

Updating rows in tables (DELETE , INSERT , UPDATE).

Loading data into tables (COPY INTO <table>).
Unloading data from tables (COPY INTO <location>)
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses

Selected Answer: CE
Correct

Selected Answer: CE
These 3 do not require active Warehouse:
Downloading data from an internal stage
Listing files in a stage
Creating and Altering table.

comments.content:
Cannot be D. Altering table does not require a compute. Alter table is not altering data. its altering the definition. like changing Column type, removing a column or adding a new column. basically CREATE, ALTER. not the DML.
A also cannot be correct. They said downloading data. it did not say clearly that Loading/Unloading data. downloading could be a downloading a file from internal stage to local machine.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Performing DML operations, such as:
Updating rows in tables (DELETE , INSERT , UPDATE). (Answer D)
Loading data into tables (COPY INTO <table>).
Unloading data from tables (COPY INTO <location>). (Answer A)
a warehouse must be running and in use for the session.

Answer is correct C&D
Materialised views are pre computed it does require warehouse.
C & D IS CORRECT

Selected Answer: CD
Not sure if materialized view will require a running cluster as data is already computed and may reside in cache. But alter table will definitely require a running cluster.

C & E
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses.html
Hmmm not sure about this, maybe E

choices.A: Downloading data from an internal stage
choices.E: Querying data from a materialized view
